Guide to the McKim Mead and White Architectural Records
circa 1875-1950

did.unittitle: McKim, Mead and White architectural records

physdesc.extent: in 677 boxes and 13 drawers, plus 15 shelves of bound volumes and 3,046 rolls of architectural drawings

did.physloc: Most of the collection is stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact printroom@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.
did.abstract: The McKim, Mead and White Architectural Collections consists of architectural drawings, correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, financial records, and specifications documenting individual projects of the firm as well as its overall operations.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The McKim, Mead and White Architectural Record Collection spans the period from ca. 1875 to 1950 and includes the major portion of the firm's records. The collection consists of more than 61,000 architectural drawings, including ink on linen, blueprints, and other media; 1,500 photographs, including prints and glass and film negatives; 700 boxes of correspondence and specifications; 54 ledgers, including 17 bill books (1878-1947), 10 cash books (1894-1944), 8 contract books (1903-1930), and 9 journals (1882-1942); 30 photo albums and scrapbooks; and more than 300 original line drawings made to illustrate A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915 (all numbers are approximate). The material contains extensive documentation of the firm's operations and of individual buildings, although most information about the firm's early years can be found in the photograph albums, clippings scrapbooks, and financial ledgers.

Included in the collection are Shingle Style, Colonial Revival, and other country houses in Newport, Rhode Island; urban residences such as the Villard Houses, New York; public commissions including Boston Public Library, Rhode Island State Capitol, and Prospect Park entrances, Brooklyn, New York; and universities, museums and libraries including the restoration of the University of Virginia rotunda, Columbia University and Pierpont Morgan Library, New York.

The collection is organized by the following formats: architectural drawings, correspondence, specifications, photographs, scrapbooks and photograph albums, newspaper and journal clippings, financial records, and publications.

More detailed finding aids for portions of the collection are available on-site. Researchers wishing to access the collection must schedule an appointment in advance. Requests for appointments and other questions should be submitted to the librarian for the Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections at printroom@nyhistory.org.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift from Lawrence Grant White, Stanford White's son, in 1950, with additions from Mrs. James Kellum Smith in 1968.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers by appointment. Appointments must be scheduled in advance by contacting the Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections at printroom@nyhistory.org.

Most of the collection is stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact printroom@nyhistory.org prior to your research visit to coordinate access. Keep in mind that it will take between two (2) and five (5) business days for collections to arrive, and you should plan your research accordingly.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles McKim (1847–1909), William Rutherford Mead (1846–1928), and Stanford White (1853–1906) established their partnership in New York City in 1879 and soon became the premier architectural firm in the United States. Between 1879 and 1912, the firm received nearly 1000 commissions, designing a wide array of residential, institutional, commercial, and public buildings in New York and other cities. Influenced by their extensive travels (and training) in Europe, the firm designed primarily in the Beaux Arts style, becoming the leading proponents of a return to classicism as an expression of American architectural character. The firm's work at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893, featuring the "White City," also helped to launch the "City Beautiful" movement.

Among the firm's many notable buildings are Pennsylvania Station (1910, razed 1963), the Morgan Library and Museum (1903, expanded 1928), the Brooklyn Museum (1895), and the Municipal Building (1909-1915).

While associated primarily with the Gilded Age, the firm continued for more than three decades after the death of the last founding partner (Mead) in 1928, and trained many significant 20th century architects, including John Carrere and Thomas Hastings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is currently organized by format into the following eight series:

Series I: Architectural drawings
Series II: Correspondence
Series III: Specifications
Series IV: Photographs
Series V: Scrapbooks and photograph albums
Series VI: Newspaper and journal clippings
Series VII: Financial records books
Series VIII: Publications

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections at the New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: The personal papers of Stanford White are held by the Library's Department of Manuscripts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as: McKim, Mead and White Architectural Records, PR 42, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, New-York Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials at Other Institutions
relatedmaterial.p: Additional McKim, Mead and White drawings and photographs are held by Columbia University's Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library.
Charles Follen McKim's papers are held by the Library of Congress' manuscript division.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p:
Researchers wishing to access architectural drawings should be aware that due to their fragility and volume, special handling procedures apply to these materials. Accordingly, researchers should consult with the Print Room Librarian about how much time to budget when scheduling an appointment to view architectural drawings.
The majority of drawings are stored on rolls; unrolling and rerolling these drawings is a time consuming process, so only a limited number of rolls can be viewed per visit. Multiple visits will be required for researchers wishing to view a significant number of drawings.
To preserve drawings for future research, the following restrictions apply:
1. All research appointments must be scheduled in advance through the Print Room Librarian.

2. Researchers will be required to wash their hands at the institution prior to handling archival materials.
3. Librarians will page only one tube or folder of architectural drawings at a time. No additional materials will be paged until all previously accessed drawings have been re-rolled and/or re-housed.
4. No drawings will be paged after 2:00 PM (or within one hour of closing time).
5. The Librarian has the discretion to limit the number of rolls a researcher may view per visit.
6. Damaged or particularly fragile drawings may, in the Librarian's discretion, be handled only under the direct supervision of a librarian or withheld pending review by the chief conservator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are approximately 61,150 rolled drawings for over 1000 commissioned projects. Approximately 65 percent of these are tracings (mostly ink on linen), and 35 percent are print duplicates (mostly blueprints on paper). They consist of plans, elevations, sections, exterior and interior details, full size details, sketches, and shop drawings. Projects include educational institutions, banks, country estates, residences, clubs and casinos, hotels, memorials, government buildings, public buildings, commercial buildings, libraries, museums, churches, and hospitals in New York and elsewhere.

The drawings were re-housed between 2009-2012 pursuant to a generous Save America's Treasures grant from the National Park Service, in partnership with the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Institute of Library and Museum Services, and the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities.
This subseries includes drawings of many of the firm's most important projects in New York City and elsewhere. An item-level inventory of the rolled drawings is available on-site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of approximately 665 hollinger boxes of documents -- primarily letters, but also a large amount of billing correspondence and some contracts. The files also occasionally include small drawings, rough sketches, specifications, photographs and clippings. A small amount of additional correspondence may be located in Series III, Specifications.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The correspondence files have been partially processed. In 2004, the original folders were rehoused into 665 document boxes. Over time some of these original folders, which are crumbling, were replaced with archival folders, but most of the series remains in the original folders.

Also in 2004, an inventory of the correspondence was prepared as a standalone Microsoft Word document. In 2020, reference librarian Jill Reichenbach transcribed the inventory into ArchivesSpace, incorporating it into this on-line finding aid.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The subseries is believed to be in its original order as received by N-YHS. It is arranged in alphabetical order by what appears to be client name. Specific files/projects within an overall client name are shown in folder level notes. Project numbers are shown in (parentheses).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Photographs series includes copy photos of architectural drawings, glass plate negatives, printed material (offprints from publications, entire publications, postcards), newspaper clippings, documents from Departments of Documents and Buildings (generally for New York City projects), handwritten notes, and sometimes correspondence or blueprints. (This series does not include photo albums; see Series V for those, along with scrapbooks.)

All folders contain photographs unless otherwise specified. For projects that have multiple folders of material, general descriptions of what is in each folder have been given. Projects that merely have a listing of their name are represented by a folder of photographs only.

Sometimes images of other buildings may appear in a specific project's file. These were found with the other photographs in the file, and often cases have manuscript notations on them to "file in [project name]". They were most likely used as models for buildings, or contained elements or ideas that were to be incorporated into the project in question.

Photographers included are Blackman Photo Service, Edwin J. Cardswell, Louis H. Dreyer, Gottscho-Schleisner, H. Ernest King, Schuyler Carteret Lee, J.C. Maugans, C. Ording, Richard Averill Smith, Adolph Studly, Tebbs Architectural Photos, Irving Underhill, United States Army Signal Corps, DeWitt Ward, and Wurts Bros.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files of photographic prints and any related materials are housed and organized by size, and arranged in alphabetical order within each size. These are followed by a set of glass plate negatives. Because of this size-oriented arrangement, a particular subject can be found in more than one subseries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Subseries IV.A and IV.B (small and medium photographs) were processed by Cailean Cooney and by Kristine Paulus, respectively, in 2004-2006. Photos were housed and an inventory prepared at that time in a Word document. In April-May 2020, reference librarian Jill Reichenbach transcribed the inventory into N-YHS's collection management system and re-published the on-line finding aid to include the full subseries IV.A and IV.B list.

Subseries IV.C (large photographs) was processed and inventoried sometime after 2006, likely around 2009-12 when the bulk of the collection was processed. Subseries IV.D. (glass negatives) were rehoused, likely also around 2009-12, but have not been inventoried.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes photograph files housed upright in 42 document boxes. The majority of these photographs are 8 x 10, but they also include small snapshots.

did.unittitle: Series V: Scrapbooks and photograph albums

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes 30 blank-paged leather-bound volumes with photographs, maps, sketches, and/or floor plans pasted in. Some of the albums have been disbound and re-housed in folders due to their deteriorating condition. Most albums depict MMW projects and are devoted to either a particular project or a general category of work. There are also a few albums of non-MMW work which probably served as sourcebooks for the firm's architects to draw ideas from.
Detailed inventories for some of the scrapbooks are available on-site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scrapbook contains maps, sketches, and photographs of building exteriors, fields, barns, dormitories, the library, Havemeyer Chemical Laboratory, staircases, general construction, and the Hall of Languages in University Heights. 1898.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This album does not appear to contain the work of MM&W. Instead, the majority of photographs and sketches concern themselves with various Beaux-Arts Architects and competitions. There are several decorative elements at the beginning of the book.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The original is restricted due to condition issues. A photocopied version (Volume SB-3.2) is available for researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprehensive collection of plans, photographs, designs and articles relating to McKim, Mead and White commissions. There are several unidentified buildings. Articles pertain to the building, construction, and controversy (such as the trustees of the Boston Public Library choosing McKim, Mead and White over the Boston city architect).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 includes images of ceiling details, doors under construction, columns waiting to be installed, and crude sculptures. The only dated photograph is from 1894, for the Power House in Niagara Falls, NY. Majority of pictures are unlabeled.
Folder 2 includes interiors, tombstones, cemeteries, unidentified houses, Shinnecock Hills, the Ascension Church, and sculptures of lions and children.

Folder 3 includes an urn, the construction of Staatsburgh, Ophir Farm, the rotunda at the University of Virginia, 110 Bleecker Street, Joseph's Pulitzer's door, a storehouse, sculptures, and unidentified buildings. Several photographs include workmen and pedestrians.

Folder 4 includes the Chandler, Whitney, and Williams houses under construction, along with the unveiling of the Peter Cooper Memorial. Scenes from what appear to be the World's Fair, and decorative elements belonging to unidentified residences also appear in the folder.
Folder 5 includes the George Williams house, the Vanderbilt residence, the Duseen (?) building, and a mausoleum. Several sites and buildings are unidentifiable.
Folder 6 includes Ferncliff Casino, the Hecker Mausoleum site, the Twombley plot, the Philadelphia Art Museum, Whitelaw Reid residence, and the Paulist Fathers Church.

Folder 7 includes Beacon Rock, the Pierpont Morgan Library, Harvard Gates, and the Knickerbocker Trust Company. There are multiple street scenes that include the Hotel Manhattan, Grand Central Station, the Astor, and the Old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Folder 8 includes the Ochre Point home of Robert Goelet, and at least two non-MM&W projects: the improvement of Copley Square, and a Roman School. There are also several unidentified houses and churches.

Folder 9 includes projects that were not designed by MM&W, including the Roman School, Mr. Treat Campbell at 298 Broadway, Fort Greene Park, Holt Monument, and what appears to be a triumphal arch. There are also several photographs highlighting construction workers, cows, landscapes, and a man standing between a column and a lightpost.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of designs are by the firm of McKim, Mead and White. Other architects are J.H. Duncan, Seth Greer, and U.H. Mullins. There are photographs of proposed sites, additions, interiors, and even an analysis of capitals. Grant's Tomb, by J.H. Duncan, is also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original drawings of architectural details such as columns and arches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original drawings of architectural details such as columns and arches

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 includes what appear to be mausoleums, and decorative elements for the exterior.

Folder 2 includes exterior photographs of residences and buildings, several photographs show the stages of construction. Some pictures are closeups of entryways. Also shows crowds of men outside the New York Herald, and the statue being placedon top of the building.

Folder 3 includes buildings in various states of construction and finish, and exterior renovations. There are also street scenes, and several pastoral scenes in photographs. One interesting photograph in folder 3 features only a man in a field of cows.
Folder 4 includes exteriors and interiors of buildings, along with street scenes. Photographs show construction, workers, pedestrians, and several photographs are of architectural models for the Girard Trust Company. Clubs, a high school, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art also feature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 9 includes photographs the floor test in the Amherst Laboratory, and the coffered ceiling detail of Winnipeg Bank.

did.unittitle: New York State College of Agriculture (Cornelius White, architect)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Majority of work in album not done by McKim, Mead and White. This appears to be a scrapbook of ideas, inspiration, and competition in the fields of architecture and sculpture.

One object of note in Folder 2 is a painting of Lady Charles Spencer. Folders 3 and 4 focus on expositions and exhibitions at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th century, including the Pan-American Exposition, Buffalo, NY; Louisiana Purchase Exposition, St. Louis, MO; Trans-Mississippi Exhibition, Omaha, NE; World's Columbia Exposition, Chicago, IL; and the Exposition of 1900, Paris, France. Architects are noted whenever possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consists of photographs of non-MM&W sculpture. Most pages are blank.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly exterior photographs of residences, the RI state capital building, a statue, and New York office buildings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Disbound photo album of commissioned McKim, Mead and White residences, buildings, gazebos and clubs. Interior photographs are included. Highlights include Box Hill, Stanford White's residence in St. James (Folder 1); the Orange Y.M.C.A. building (Folder 2); and a spectacular bird's eye view of Naugatuck, CT (Folder 7). Also features work commissioned by Edwin Dennison Morgan, John Jacob Astor IV, C.H. Mackay, George G. King, University of Virginia, L.C. Hanna, the Sherry Casino, and Dr. R.H. Derby.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound album of commissioned McKim, Mead and White residence, buildings, gazebos and clubs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: None of the work represented in the album was designed by McKim, Mead and White. This most probably served as an architectural sourcebook for the architects to draw ideas from. Photographs show architectural details, interiors, facades, tombs, monuments, and other sculptural and architectural elements. Also includes copies of floor plans for many palaces and residences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Architectural scrapbook of ideas for the firm of McKim, Mead and White. Iron-work dominates the folder. Many photographs are from the Museo Nazionale in Naples, Italy. There is one double-helix staircase that bears a strong resemblance to the double-helix staircase at Rosecliff, a mansion the firm designed and built between 1897-1902.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes work commissioned by Hamilton McKay Twombly, owner of Florham Farms in Madison, NJ, and a residence for George A. Nickerson, in Boston, MA. Also included is another unidentified residence.

did.unittitle: Walker O. Cain & Associates, Book of photographs by Mr. Mead

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject matter includes buildings, plans, decorative elements, and elevations from apartment houses to the Payne Whitney House (includes many unidentified projects). There are also photographs of construction sites, alleyways, streets, and parks.

did.unittitle: Report of the Washington Park Commission

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of the construction and completion of the Rotunda, buildings in the South Lawn Complex, and Rouss Hall are featured in the album. Also included are interior photographs, and several shots of arcades.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs in the first 5 folders focus on the construction of the Columbia College Library. A few photographs from the completed building show students using the Reading Room. Folders 5 and 6 show construction on the University Building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 7 shows the construction of and completed Physics Building. Folders 8 and 9 focus on the Natural Science Building. There are other photographs in folder 9 of the Engineering Building. The Chemistry Building is shown in folders 9 and 10. Folder 12 has a few photos of Hamilton Hall.

did.unittitle: Series VI: Newspaper and journal clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of newspaper and magazine clippings concerning McKim, Mead and White projects; also included are special reprints of clippings and of published photographs. The clippings were originally pasted in volumes which have been disbound due to their deteriorating condition.

did.unittitle: New York City Architect, Vol. 2, No. 5, "City Investing Building: A Tribute."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes 54 volumes of financial records books, divided into the following seven categories: bill books, cash books, journal books, ledger books, contract books, and miscellaneous financial records books. The bill books include typed carbon copies of accounts; the remaining books consist primarily of handwritten financial account ledgers.
For additional copies of bills and statements, see Series II, Correspondence.

did.unittitle: Subseries V.6: Other Financial Records Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes two boxes of what appear to be proof plates for A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915, published in phases from 1915 to 1920, as well as the plates for McKim, Mead and White houses and casinos featured in George William Sheldon's Artistic Country-Seats, published in 1886.
Also included is the firm's copy of the 1899 Sanborn fire insurance Atlas of New York City.
The Print Room also holds a complete set of the original plates for A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915. The call number for the set is Print Room Rare NA737.MR A5 1915.
